The problem with Thanksgiving is that it is all so fake. Everyone says they are grateful for this or that but  no one truly appreciates things on a deeper level. People still take things for granted. The holiday has become an excuse for every American home to slaughter a bird  and eat too much of food that isnt good for you with your family. Where has the meaning gone? Do we just blindly follow traditions without thinking about what we are actually doing, because we are used to doing it? Are the morals that Thanksgiving is trying to teach being neglected? Should we not be expressing these morals year round? Why limit our gratitude for what we have to a single day?
Appreciate what you have. You never realize how much you care about something until you no longer have it.

Don't rely on how much you see it on the news and, consequently, how easily you can recall it (availability heuristic). Look at the actual statistics. While it is true that many studies have discovered a strong correlation (and some even a causation via experimental random selection), it is also true that studies have found NO LONG TERM effect. So, to draw an inappropriate comparison: a child watching a sex scene will undoubtedly get more horny in the time immediately after watching, but in the long run will be no more horny than any other pubescent adolescent or post-pubescent adult.

Hey Fox, news flash: not every video game isnt Call of Duty or Grand Theft Auto. There are games for kids too. For example, Super Mario Bros, Super Smash Bros., Mario Kart and many more great games that Im missing (Sorry Xbox, PlayStation, and PC fanboys ). There is also a thing called the ESRB. Its similar to ratings for movies except for games. For games, the ratings are: E, E10+, T, M, and AO18+. E is the equivalent to G, E10+ is the equivalent to PG, T is equivalent to PG-13, M is the equivalent to R, and AO18+ is the equivalent to NC-17. AO18+ is not allowed to be sold and stores and M rated games cannot be sold to someone under 17 without parental guidance so...Its the parents fault! Not only that, games dont cause violence! Call of Duty isnt going to make me become full trained for war, Super Mario isnt going to give me he ability to jump high and shoot fireballs, and NBA 2K isnt going to make me a professional basketball player. Wanna know why!? I know the difference between fiction and reality! The kids shooting up schools because of video games isnt possible because either 1. They dont know the difference between fiction and reality are 18 and somehow got the gun, or 2. They were bullied and just couldnt take it anymore, so they decided to let out the AK on their bullies. In conclusion, instead of blaming games for violence and school shoots, we should amp up the gun law age to 21 along with a background check (dont give guns to the mentally ill) and show the gamers (who have problems telling the difference between reality and fiction), the difference between reality and fiction cause most of us gamers know the difference and we arent violent. Oh my goodness. How disingenuous can you be? The Military uses specific kinds of simulations, THAT THEY MAKE, in order to to train military personnel. They aren't training on games played by the general public. You're not training soldiers on COD in hopes that it will improve their chances of survival.
I can pretty much guarantee that Grossman failed to interview anyone with significant knowledge of video games when writing his book. 9 times out of ten, he, and the others on the panel, are obsessing over the violence far more then a person playing the game is. If you only learned about video games through them, you'd think that violence was the only point of the games. That's not even remotely the case. Games tend to be about problem solving and are objective based. A player is going to be focusing on the task at hand and working towards an objective. This is often involving activities such as going from point A to point B. Enemies are, more or less, obstacles in the way of completing an objective. Winning objectives is what a player is focusing on, not salivating over gratuitous violence.
If you're going to talk about video games, at least try to learn about the perspectives of those involved in them rather than insert your own worldviews onto them. At least give them that much respect. I find that the vast majority of pundits and so called 'expert' know little to nothing about what they are talking about when it comes to video games.

Answer is an unfortunate yes and no. Generally speaking, in a home where love is present and morality is taught, video games are harmless, regardless of nature. However in a home where both are lacking and violent video game interaction is uncontrolled/unmonitored, then such stimulation may -or may not, even - lead to real life re-enactment.
Obviously, there are many, many more factors at play here that can lead to video games being an influence (or not) in ones mind.
Moral of the debate: love your children. Teach your children. Be a parent. Video games can be okay, but as with all things, should be in moderation. And you, as a parent, should know your child and should determine whether such is acceptable or not. Does your child enjoy plucking wings off of birds? Then video games might not be the best idea. If youre a gun owner, do you teach responsibility and morality and respect of the tool? So many, many things at play here... people just simply need to be responsible. Otherwise, we lose rights and conformity is legislated into place.

Now, Im in no position to say whats right and wrong when it comes to parenting, I know its a tough job; but if you dont want children to play these violent games that they need your permission to acquire, then dont buy them. Or maybe just be more diligent about certain aspects of what they experience? Over-sheltering can have just as bad an outcome as blatant exposure, so maybe moderation is in order. The first step is to not give them any games of this nature until they are old enough to make reasonable assessments about the world around them; and then make sure they know the differences between reality and video games. If we were to ever ban violent video games, it would just be something else next; and people would just keep blaming different types of media until theres absolutely no entertainment industry. All because people and many parents in particular refuse to take responsibility for what their children are allowed to be exposed to when theyre at home.

I remember that one time I played a video game. I was a 22 year old single father, life was hitting me hard since I got a divorce from that bitch of a ex-wife. I decided to let off some steam by playing the 2016 version of DOOM on my trusty PS4, that console was the only thing my wife didnt throw out. I remember the game vividly, tearing out heads of hell spawn and blasting them open with a shotgun. It was exciting, it gave me a rush, playing DOOM made me feel like I was on drugs, it had a solid unmoving grip on me. My daughter, whos 7 years old, came down the stairs yelling Hey dad look what I found! That sentence made me snap out of my video game induced high, my daughter yanked me back to the cold, awful situation in reality. Playing DOOM snapped something inside of me, my daughter daring to interrupt my video game time made me violently angry. GO BACK TO YOUR ROOM YOU LITTLE SHIT!!! I bellowed, she had to know better than to dare take my attention away from my video game and forcing me to face how shit my life had became. She yelled back at me, saying how mom wont yell at her like that, and that she was a much better parent. Those words had made me throw away any sense of calmness I had. I threw the controller down on the ground with the force of an insanely angry 22 year old white neckbread, which caused my daughter to retreat back into her room, screaming and crying. Those screechs emitting our of my daughter only made me angrier, I jolted to my room, opposite of my daughters and found the key I was looking for. I used it to unlock the black locker that was sitting next to my bed. Inside the case was my double barrel shotgun, which I used to hunt ducks. Grabbing it made me feel like actually in DOOM (since the Doom guy also used a shotgun), and that my daughter was a demon out to kill me. I rushed into my daughters room, bashing down the locked door with the might of a thousand screeching autistic children and screamed FUCK YOU DEMON SCUM FUCK!!! I unloaded my shotgun into the incarnation of all my problems in my pathetic life known as my daughter. I remember her face being shocked as I unloaded a shell into her head, causing it to gush open, spilling out brain guts and blood on to her pink wall. It wasnt long after I murdered my daughter that I realized what I had done. Playing DOOM snapped something inside me, causing me to become incredibly violent and angry, it wasnt my own fault, or my alcoholism, or my hodge podge of mental illnesses! It was that video game, DOOM 2016 for the PS4. I rushed to my car, shotgun still in my grasp and drove out of town, panicking. Now I am currently typing this story, I still have one shell left in my shotgun, and I plan to use it on myself. I wanted to get the message out to people, that video games do cause violence, not anger, disorders, or mental illnesses, but video games, they caused something to snap within me. They are not safe, and they ALL need to be banned from the U.S before they cause more violence. God damn it now I hear the cops coming, I would say more but I dont feel like going to jail. Goodbye.

I usually don't like to leave comments. But sometimes I feel very strongly about something and I just want to point some things out to people watching who may not know a ton about the situation. First of all, notice how biased the anchor-woman is. She makes no effort to stay neutral in this debate whatsoever. Second, notice how much time they allow each debater to talk. Now I want you to pay attention to how much statistical data each debater presented as fact. NOT opinion or speculation, but evidence. 
The truth is that these games are spread out across the world. There are children playing them in Europe and Asia just as frequently as the United States. But violence isn't as common in these other countries. This alone is a HUGE factor when considering whether or not video games are a leading cause of violence.
This was stated in the video, but I would again like to bring up the fact that these games have a rating system in place that is meant to keep violent content from getting into the hands of children who may not be mature enough to witness it. Sorry to say this, Rhett and Link, and I love you guys, but milk DOES NOT do the body good. It contains hormones that were never designed for any other species to consume and are intended to help baby calves grow up strong. Also, milk is loaded with fat and sugar in ever glass, sure it has calcium and vitamin D, but that does not nearly override all of these other factors that make milk so terrible for you. Think about it. We are the ONLY species in the world that consumes milk from another, completely different, species. Oh, and by the way, if you still don't believe me when I say that milk is bad for you, there are several articles online certified or made by medical professionals that disprove the whole, "Milk is great for you!" theory.
